qas.question: Where has the rule of law been more of a theory than a way of life?
According to what principles are most laws in Thailand decided?
In Thailand, what branch of government rejected a proposal for senator selection?
When did Thailand first try to overthrow its government run by a king?
What harms the adherence to the Constitution in Thailand?
What kingdom has not had a Constitution since 1932?
What has been practiced in Thailand since 1932?
What has been eradicated from the three branches of Thailand's government?
What is no longer advocated in Thailand since the twenty-first century?
Whose decision did the Supreme Court reject in Thailand?

context: In <a0_0><b5_0>Thailand<a0_0/>,<b5_0/> a kingdom that has had a constitution since the initial attempt to overthrow the absolute monarchy system in <a3_0>1932<a3_0/>, <b6_0>the rule of law<b6_0/> has been more of a principle than actual practice.[citation needed] <a4_0><b7_0>Ancient prejudices and political bias<b7_0/><a4_0/> have been present in the three branches of government with each of their foundings, and justice has been processed formally according to the law but in fact more closely aligned with <a1_0><b8_0>royalist<a1_0/> principles<b8_0/> that are still advocated in the 21st century.[citation needed] In November 2013, Thailand faced still further threats to the rule of law when <b9_0>the <a2_0>executive branch<b9_0/><a2_0/> rejected a supreme court decision over how to select senators.[citation needed]
